awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: When Locals Adapt to Newcomers
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates the effects affluent newcomers have on poor communities in a developing region when they become a newcomer community of lifestyle migrants. Some are retirees who hope to stretch their pensions by living in a cheaper location and some are younger people looking for adventure, a slower pace of life, or cheaper cost of living in a beautiful place. Many open businesses and employ household staff in an area where most locals work in the tourism industry. Understanding these newcomers' relations with locals is important because their role as entrepreneurs, bosses, and landowners could be increasing differences in economic opportunities in a peaceful, democratic region.  This project advances the study of migration and mixing, gentrification in rural communities, and retirement, specifically filling a gap in understanding how privileged migrants affect local economies and social relations.

The main sources of data for this project will be interviews and ethnographic research.  Forty-five interviews with lifestyle migrants from two different outside regions will be conducted as well as 40 interviews with locals.  The ethnographic component will consist of one year of participant observation of migrant-run businesses and households, community events, and social gatherings in five small towns.  Snowball sampling will be used for interviewee selection, and opportunistic sampling to determine where participant observation will occur.  The research questions addressed concern how outsiders' advantageous economic position affects their influence and how the economic and influence resources of lifestyle migrants affect locals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project I explored the impact that North American and European migrants have when they move to beach towns in Costa Rica. Migration scholars usually consider people moving from wealthy to poor countries, often called “lifestyle migrants, to be motivated by desire for a relaxing life in a beautiful place with natural amenities. While this is true for the expat migrant participants in my study, I found that many also needed to work to support themselves. They did this primarily by becoming business entrepreneurs in the local host economy focused on serving tourists or by working remotely for employers in their home countries. The financial resources that most expats bring with them to Costa Rica makes them much wealthier than locals; they can buy houses and land, start businesses, and spend more on living expenses. Expats also have national, race, and educational privilege that sets them apart from local Costa Ricans.

Due to these advantages, I hypothesized that expats might foster reverse integration, a situation where locals accommodate and integrate into the social norms of expat immigrants rather than expats integrating into the norms of locals. The project posed several questions: 1) How do lifestyle migrants in Costa Rica translate their economic power into political power? 2) What is the impact of the economic and political resources of lifestyle migrants on local Costa Rican individuals and communities? 3) Do the economic, social, and political capital of lifestyle migrants contribute to economic development and advancement of local populations through increased education, language acquisition, cultural capital? Conversely, does lifestyle migration further impoverish and marginalize local populations who are forced into situations of reverse integration?

            To investigate these questions, I spent five months, from July to December 2019, conducting fieldwork in towns on the Caribbean coast of Costa Rica. During that time, I conducted 29 in-depth interviews and dozens of informal interviews with local Costa Ricans and with North American and European immigrants. The interviews supplemented ethnographic observations about interactions between immigrants and locals in private homes, businesses, NGO offices, and the beach and other public settings.

By exploring the day-to-day interactions and organization of expat-local relations, the project describes and analyzes this growing transnational phenomenon. In particular, I document several aspects of expat-local relations: expats’ formal activities as business entrepreneurs, expats’ roles as private employers of service workers (maids, gardeners, handymen), the extent of expats’ informal activities as friends and intimate “gift givers” in relationships that involve lending money or providing material goods in personal exchanges.

My research has generated two major findings: 1) The economic dominance of expats who own businesses and real estate has increased inequality on the Caribbean coast, causing locals to have substantially less access to business ownership, land ownership, and education compared to that of migrants, and 2) reverse integration exists to an extent: while some locals must adapt to the cultural expectations of their expat employers, primarily by learning or improving their English, locals also resist immigrants’ economic power and cultural values by maintaining social distance in work and social relationships.

Studying the outcomes of highly privileged migration is important because increasing numbers of Euro-Americans work remotely in countries where the cost of living is lower than their home countries.  Additional factors shaping relatively wealthy migrants’ decisions to move abroad include the authorization of digital nomad visas in developing countries and inflation that pushes expats to look for cost-cutting options for retirement.
